SUMMARY:  INNER | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL:  FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.ibm.xmi.framework
Interface WriterAdapter

All Known Subinterfaces:
DeclarationWriterAdapter, ObjectWriterAdapter
All Known Implementing Classes:
WriterAdapterImpl
public interface WriterAdapter

This interface defines methods used by both the ObjectWriterAdapter interface and the DeclarationWriterAdapter interface. You implement an ObjectWriterAdapter interface so the framework can serialize your objects to XMI files if the objects do not implement framework interfaces or inherit from the framework classes. You implement a DeclarationWriterAdapter so the framework can create XMI DTDs and schemas from your data that corresponds to framework classes and packages.

You need to implement the following methods if you are using sets of tag values for objects to be serialized to XMI files or if you want to specify tag values to tailor the generation of XMI schemas.

  • getSets
  • getTags
  • getTagValue

You may return null or an empty collection for methods in the interface that do not pertain to your problem domain. If a method returns a string or Namespace, you can return null if the method is not relevant; if a method returns a collection, you can return an empty collection.

The framework has not been optimized, so the methods in this interface are called repeatedly. If it is expensive to implement a method, you should consider caching the information that is returned so future calls to the method will work more quickly.

Method Detail

getContents

public java.util.Collection getContents(java.lang.Object extensionOrXMLElementOrPackage)
Return the contents of the given XMI extension, XML element, or package, or an empty collection if there are no contents.

Implement this method if you want XMI extensions to be written to an XMI file (and you are not using sets of tag values to do it), or if you want a package to be written to a DTD or schema.

Parameters:
extensionOrXMLElementOrPackage - An XMI extension, XML element, or package
Returns:
The contents of the given construct

getFeatures

public java.util.Collection getFeatures(java.lang.Object xmiClass)
Return a collection of features for the given class, or an empty collection if there are no features. This method is used when serializing values of objects if the values need to be serialized according to the order of features of classes. This method is also used when creating XMI DTDs and schemas.
Parameters:
xmiClass - An object corresponding to an XMIClass
Returns:
The features for the class, or an empty collection

getNamespace

public Namespace getNamespace(java.lang.Object data)
Return the namespace for the given data.

You may always return null if you are working with XMI 1.0, or you are working with XMI 1.1 and do not need to use XML namespaces.

Parameters:
data - A Java object representing data to write to a file or dtd.
Returns:
The namespace, or null if there is none.

getOwner

public java.lang.Object getOwner(java.lang.Object data)
Return the owner for the given piece of data. If data corresponds to a framework value, the owner is the object it belongs to. If data corresponds to a framework feature, the owner is the class it belongs to. If data corresponds to a class, the owner is the package it belongs to. If data is a package, the owner is the package that contains it.

The framework uses this method when computing XMI names.

Parameters:
data - An object representing either a package, class, feature, or value.
Returns:
The owner, or null if there is none.

getSets

public java.util.Collection getSets(java.lang.Object data)
Return the names of sets of tag values for the given data, or an empty collection if there are none.
Parameters:
data - A construct in the framework object model
Returns:
A collection of set names (java.lang.String), or an empty collection

getSuperclasses

public java.util.Collection getSuperclasses(java.lang.Object xmiClass)
Return the immediate superclasses of the given class, or an empty collection if there are no superclasses.

This method is used when writing DTDs and schemas, as well as when serializing values of objects, if the values need to be serialized according to the order features appear in classes.

Parameters:
xmiClass - A Java object corresponding to a class
Returns:
The immediate superclasses of the class, or an empty collection

getTags

public java.util.Collection getTags(java.lang.Object data,
                                    java.lang.String setName)
Return the names of tags in the given set of tag values for the given data, or an empty collection if there are none.
Parameters:
data - An object corresponding to a framework construct in the framework object model.
setName - The name of the set of tag values
Returns:
A collection of tag names (java.lang.String), or an empty collection

getTagValue

public java.lang.String getTagValue(java.lang.Object object,
                                    java.lang.String setName,
                                    java.lang.String tagName)
Return the value of the given tag in the given set of tag values for the given object, or null.
Parameters:
object - An XMI object
setName - The name of the set of tag values
tagName - The name of the tag
Returns:
The value of the tag or null

getType

public int getType(java.lang.Object data)
Return the type of the given data. For values, return their type. For features, return their value type.

If data is an object, return WriterAdapter.OBJECT; class, WriterAdapter.CLASS; package, WriterAdapter.PACKAGE; and XML element, WriterAdapter.XML_ELEMENT.

Parameters:
data - A Java object corresponding to a value, object, feature, class, package, or XML element.
Returns:
One of the valid types.

getXMIName

public java.lang.String getXMIName(java.lang.Object data)
Return the XMI name for the given object, value, class, feature, package, or XML element (if you are using XMI extensions).
Parameters:
data - Your Java object that corresponds either an object, value, class, feature, package, or XML element
Returns:
The XMI name

getFeatureType

public java.lang.Object getFeatureType(java.lang.Object feature)
Return the type of a feature. This will be an object representing either a framework datatype, enumeration, or class.
Parameters:
feature - An object corresponding to a framework feature.
Returns:
The type of the feature, or null.
